fluff.name: Monk
entries: Her fists a blur as they deflect an incoming hail of arrows, a half-elf springs over a barricade and throws herself into the massed ranks of hobgoblins on the other side. She whirls among them, knocking their blows aside and sending them reeling, until at last she stands alone.
Taking a deep breath, a human covered in tattoos settles into a battle stance. As the first charging orcs reach him, he exhales and a blast of fire roars from his mouth, engulfing his foes.

Moving with the silence of the night, a black-clad halfling steps into a shadow beneath an arch and emerges from another inky shadow on a balcony a stone's throw away. She slides her blade free of its cloth-wrapped scabbard and peers through the open window at the tyrant prince, so vulnerable in the grip of sleep.

Whatever their discipline, monks are united in their ability to magically harness the energy that flows in their bodies. Whether channeled as a striking display of combat prowess or a subtler focus of defensive ability and speed, this energy infuses all that a monk does.

entries.name: The Magic of Ki
entries: Monks make careful study of a magical energy that most monastic traditions call ki. This energy is an element of the magic that suffuses the multiverseâ€”specifically, the element that flows through living bodies. Monks harness this power within themselves to create magical effects and exceed their bodies' physical capabilities, and some of their special attacks can hinder the flow of ki in their opponents. Using this energy, monks channel uncanny speed and strength into their unarmed strikes. As they gain experience, their martial training and their mastery of ki gives them more power over their bodies and the bodies of their foes.

entries.name: Training and Asceticism
entries: Small walled cloisters dot the landscapes of the worlds of D&D, tiny refuges from the flow of ordinary life, where time seems to stand still. The monks who live there seek personal perfection through contemplation and rigorous training. Many entered the monastery as children, sent to live there when their parents died, when food couldn't be found to support them, or in return for some kindness that the monks had performed for their families.

Some monks live entirely apart from the surrounding population, secluded from anything that might impede their spiritual progress. Others are sworn to isolation, emerging only to serve as spies or assassins at the command of their leader, a noble patron, or some other mortal or divine power.

The majority of monks don't shun their neighbors, making frequent visits to nearby towns or villages and exchanging their service for food and other goods. As versatile warriors, monks often end up protecting their neighbors from monsters or tyrants.

For a monk, becoming an adventurer means leaving a structured, communal lifestyle to become a wanderer. This can be a harsh transition, and monks don't undertake it lightly. Those who leave their cloisters take their work seriously, approaching their adventures as personal tests of their physical and spiritual growth. As a rule, monks care little for material wealth and are driven by a desire to accomplish a greater mission than merely slaying monsters and plundering their treasure.

entries.name: Creating a Monk
entries: As you make your monk character, think about your connection to the monastery where you learned your skills and spent your formative years. Were you an orphan or a child left on the monastery's threshold? Did your parents promise you to the monastery in gratitude for a service performed by the monks? Did you enter this secluded life to hide from a crime you committed? Or did you choose the monastic life for yourself?

Consider why you left. Did the head of your monastery choose you for a particularly important mission beyond the cloister? Perhaps you were cast out because of some violation of the community's rules. Did you dread leaving, or were you happy to go? Is there something you hope to accomplish outside the monastery? Are you eager to return to your home?
As a result of the structured life of a monastic community and the discipline required to harness ki, monks are almost always lawful in alignment.

entries.name: Quick Build
entries: You can make a monk quickly by following these suggestions. First, make Dexterity your highest ability score, followed by Wisdom. Second, choose the {@background hermit} background.
Do not mistake my silence for acceptance of your villainy. While you blustered and threatened, I've planned four different ways to snap your neck with my bare hands.

Monks walk a path of contradiction. They study their art as a wizard does, and like a wizard, they wear no armor and typically eschew weapons. Yet they are deadly combatants, their abilities on a par with those of a raging barbarian or a superbly trained fighter. Monks embrace this seeming contradiction, for it speaks to the core of all monastic study. By coming to know oneself completely, one learns much of the wider world.

A monk's focus on inner mastery leads many such individuals to become detached from society, more concerned with their personal experience than with happenings elsewhere. Adventuring monks are a rare breed of an already rare type of character, taking their quest for perfection beyond the walls of the monastery into the world at large.
Playing a monk character offers many intriguing opportunities to try something different. To distinguish your monk character even further, consider the options in the sections that follow.

entries.name: Monastery
entries: A monk studies in a monastery in preparation for a life of asceticism. Most of those who enter a monastery make it their home for the rest of their lives, with the exception of adventurers and others who have reason to leave. For those individuals, a monastery might serve as a refuge between excursions to the world or as a source of support in times of need.
What sort of place was your monastery, and where is it located? Did attending it contribute to your experience in an unusual or distinctive way?

entries.caption: Monastery
rows: Your monastery is carved out of a mountainside, where it looms over a treacherous pass.
Your monastery is high in the branches of an immense tree in the Feywild.
Your monastery was founded long ago by a cloud giant and is inside a cloud castle that can be reached only by flying.
Your monastery is built beside a volcanic system of hot springs, geysers, and sulfur pools. You regularly received visits from azer traders.
Your monastery was founded by gnomes and is an underground labyrinth of tunnels and rooms.
Your monastery was carved from an iceberg in the frozen reaches of the world.

entries.name: Icon
entries: Even in the monastic lifestyle, which eschews materialism and personal possessions, symbolism plays an important part in defining the identity of an order. Some monastic orders treat certain creatures with special regard, either because the creature is tied to the order's history or because it serves as an example of a quality the monks seek to emulate.

If your character's monastery had a special icon, you might wear a crude image of the creature somewhere inconspicuous on your clothing to serve as an identifying mark. Or perhaps your order's icon does not have a physical form but is expressed through a gesture or a posture that you adopt, and which other monks might know how to interpret.

entries.caption: Icon
rows: Monkey. Quick reflexes and the ability to travel through the treetops are two of the reasons why your order admires the monkey.
Dragon Turtle. The monks of your seaside monastery venerate the dragon turtle, reciting ancient prayers and offering garlands of flowers to honor this living spirit of the sea.
Ki-rin. Your monastery sees its main purpose as watching over and protecting the land in the manner of the ki-rin.
Owlbear. The monks of your monastery revere a family of owlbears and have coexisted with them for generations.
Hydra. Your order singles out the hydra for its ability to unleash several attacks simultaneously.
Dragon. A dragon once laired within your monastery. Its influence remains long after its departure.

entries.name: Master
entries: During your studies, you were likely under the tutelage of a master who imparted to you the precepts of the order. Your master was the one most responsible for shaping your understanding of the martial arts and your attitude toward the world. What sort of person was your master, and how did your relationship with your master affect you?

entries.caption: Master
rows: Your master was a tyrant whom you had to defeat in single combat to complete your instruction.
Your master was kindly and taught you to pursue the cause of peace.
Your master was merciless in pushing you to your limits. You nearly lost an eye during one especially brutal practice session.
Your master seemed goodhearted while tutoring you, but betrayed your monastery in the end.
Your master was cold and distant. You suspect that the two of you might be related.
Your master was kind and generous, never critical of your progress. Nevertheless, you feel you never fully lived up to the expectations placed on you.

classFeature.name: Martial Arts
entries: Your practice of martial arts gives you mastery of combat styles that use your Unarmed Strike and Monk weapons, which are the following:

items: Martial Melee Weapons that have the Light property

entries: You gain the following benefits while you are unarmed or wielding only Monk weapons and you aren't wearing armor or wielding a Shield.

items.name: Bonus Unarmed Strike.
items.entry: You can make an Unarmed Strike as a Bonus Action.

items.name: Martial Arts Die.
items.entry: You can roll {@dice 1d6} in place of the normal damage of your Unarmed Strike or Monk weapons. This die changes as you gain Monk levels, as shown in the Martial Arts column of the Monk Features table.

items.name: Dexterous Attacks.
items.entry: You can use your Dexterity modifier instead of your Strength modifier for the attack and damage rolls of your Unarmed Strikes and Monk weapons. In addition, when you use the {@action Grapple|Ishiir} or {@action Shove|Ishiir} option of your Unarmed Strike, you can use your Dexterity modifier instead of your Strength modifier to determine the save DC.

classFeature.name: Unarmored Defense
entries: While you are wearing no armor and not wielding a shield, your AC equals 10 + your Strength or Dexterity modifier (your choice) + your Wisdom modifier.

classFeature.name: Dedicated Weapon
entries: You train yourself to use a variety of weapons as monk weapons, not just simple melee weapons and shortswords. Whenever you finish a {@variantrule Short Rest|Ishiir} or a {@variantrule Long Rest|Ishiir}, you can touch one weapon, focus your ki on it, and then count that weapon as a monk weapon until you use this feature again.
The chosen weapon must meet these criteria:

items: The weapon must be a {@filter simple or martial weapon|items|source=phb|category=basic|type=martial weapon;simple weapon|property=!heavy;!special}.
You must be proficient with it.
It must lack the heavy and special properties.

classFeature.name: Ki
entries: Your focus and martial training allow you to harness a well of extraordinary energy within yourself. This energy is represented by Ki Points. Your Monk level determines the amount of Ki Points you have, as shown in the Ki Points column of the Monk Features table.
You can expend these points to enhance or fuel certain Monk features. You start knowing three such features: Flurry of Blows, Patient Defense, and Step of the Wind, each of which is detailed below.
When you expend Ki Points, it is unavailable until you finish a {@variantrule Short Rest|Ishiir} or a {@variantrule Long Rest|Ishiir}, at the end of which you regain all your expended Ki Points.
Some features that use Ki Points require your target to make a {@variantrule Saving Throw|Ishiir}. The save DC equals 8 plus your Wisdom modifier and {@variantrule Proficiency|Ishiir} Bonus.

items.name: Flurry of Blows.
items.entry: You can expend 1 Ki Point to make two Unarmed Strikes as a Bonus Action.

items.name: Patient Defense.
items.entry: You can take the {@action Disengage|Ishiir} action as a Bonus Action. Alternatively, you can expend 1 Ki Point to take both the {@action Disengage|Ishiir} and the {@action Dodge|Ishiir} actions as a Bonus Action.

items.name: Step of the Wind.
items.entry: You can take the Dash action as a Bonus Action. Alternatively, you can expend 1 Ki Point to take both the {@action Disengage|Ishiir} and {@action Dash|Ishiir} actions as a Bonus Action, and your jump distance is doubled for the turn.

classFeature.name: Ki Features
entries: You get access to the following features.

items.name: Distant Eye.
entries: When you make a ranged weapon attack, you can spend 1 ki point to prevent attacking at long range from imposing {@variantrule Disadvantage|Ishiir} on your {@variantrule Attack Roll|Ishiir}s until the end of the current turn.

items.name: Quickened Healing.
entries: At the start of your turn, you can spend 2 ki points and roll a Martial Arts die. You regain a number of hit points equal to the number rolled.

classFeature.name: Unarmored Movement
entries: Your {@variantrule Speed|Ishiir} increases by 10 feet while you are not wearing armor or wielding a shield. This bonus increases when you reach certain monk levels, as shown in the Monk table.
At 9th level, you gain the ability to move along vertical surfaces and across liquids on your turn without falling during the move.

classFeature.name: Uncanny Metabolism
entries: When you roll Initiative, you can regain all expended Focus Points. When you do so, roll your Martial Arts die, and regain a number of Hit Points equal to your Monk level plus the number rolled.
Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|Ishiir}.

classFeature.name: Deflect Attacks
entries: When an {@variantrule Attack Roll|Ishiir} hits you and its damage includes Bludgeoning, Piercing, or Slashing damage, you can take a Reaction to reduce the attack's total damage against you. The reduction equals {@dice 1d10} plus your Dexterity modifier and Monk level.

If you reduce the damage to 0, you can expend 1 Focus Point to redirect some of the attack's force. If you do so, choose a creature you can see within 5 feet of yourself if the attack was a melee attack or a creature you can see within 60 feet of yourself that isn't behind Total Cover if the attack was a ranged attack. That creature must succeed on a Dexterity {@variantrule Saving Throw|Ishiir} or take damage equal to two rolls of your Martial Arts die plus your Dexterity modifier. The damage is the same type dealt by the attack.

classFeature.name: Monastic Tradition
entries: You commit yourself to a monastic tradition, chosen from the list of available traditions. Your tradition grants you features at 3rd level and again at 6th, 11th, and 17th level.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Martial Mastery
entries: You gain the mastery benefits for two {@filter weapons|items|source=ishiir|type=|category=|homebrew mastery=!none;!light;!medium;!heavy} of your choice as well as an {@filter armor|items|source=ishiir|type=|category=|homebrew mastery=!none;light;medium;heavy} type (see {@variantrule Armor Mastery|Ishiir} and {@variantrule Weapon Mastery|Ishiir} variant rules). You must be proficient in the chosen weapons and armor. If you possess the Unarmored Defense feature, you may {@optfeature Unarmored Defense|Ishiir|choose it} in place of an armor type.
You can change your choices when you finish a {@variantrule Short Rest|Ishiir} or a {@variantrule Long Rest|Ishiir}.

classFeature.name: {@variantrule Proficiency|Ishiir} Versatility
entries: When you gain the Ability Score Improvement feature from your class, you can also replace one of your skill proficiencies with a skill {@variantrule Proficiency|Ishiir} offered by your class at 1st level (the {@variantrule Proficiency|Ishiir} you replace needn't be from the class).
This change represents one of your skills atrophying as you focus on a different skill.

classFeature.name: Slow Fall
entries: You can use your reaction when you fall to reduce any falling damage you take by an amount equal to five times your monk level.

classFeature.name: Extra Attack
entries: You can attack twice, instead of once, whenever you take the {@action Attack|Ishiir} action on your turn.

classFeature.name: Focused Aim
entries: When you miss with an {@variantrule Attack Roll|Ishiir}, you can spend 1 to 3 ki points to increase your {@variantrule Attack Roll|Ishiir} by 2 for each of these ki points you spend, potentially turning the miss into a hit.

classFeature.name: Stunning Strike
entries: You can interfere with the flow of ki in an opponent's body. When you hit another creature with a melee weapon attack, you can spend 1 ki point to attempt a stunning strike. The target must succeed on a Constitution {@variantrule Saving Throw|Ishiir} or be {@condition Stunned|Ishiir} until the end of your next turn.

classFeature.name: Ki-Empowered Strikes
entries: Your unarmed strikes count as magical for the purpose of overcoming {@variantrule Resistance|Ishiir} and {@variantrule Immunity|Ishiir} to nonmagical attacks and damage.

classFeature.name: Monastic Tradition feature
entries: You gain one feature granted by your Monastic Tradition.

classFeature.name: Evasion
entries: When you're subjected to an effect that allows you to make a Dexterity {@variantrule Saving Throw|Ishiir} to take only half damage, you instead take no damage if you succeed on the {@variantrule Saving Throw|Ishiir} and only half damage if you fail.
You don't benefit from this feature if you have the {@condition Incapacitated|Ishiir} condition.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: {@variantrule Proficiency|Ishiir} Versatility
entries: When you gain the Ability Score Improvement feature from your class, you can also replace one of your skill proficiencies with a skill {@variantrule Proficiency|Ishiir} offered by your class at 1st level (the {@variantrule Proficiency|Ishiir} you replace needn't be from the class).
This change represents one of your skills atrophying as you focus on a different skill.

classFeature.name: Unarmored Movement improvement
entries: You gain the ability to move along vertical surfaces and across liquids on your turn without falling during the move.

classFeature.name: Purity of Body
entries: Your mastery of the ki flowing through you makes you {@variantrule Immunity|Ishiir|Immune} to disease and poison.

classFeature.name: Heightened Focus
entries: Your Flurry of Blows, Patient Defense, and Step of the Wind gain the following benefits.

items.name: Flurry of Blows.
items.entry: You can expend 1 Focus Point to use Flurry of Blows and make three Unarmed Strikes with it instead of two.

items.name: Patient Defense.
items.entry: When you expend a Focus Point to use Patient Defense, you gain a number of Temporary Hit Points equal to two rolls of your Martial Arts die.

items.name: Step of the Wind.
items.entry: When you expend a Focus Point to use Step of the Wind, you can choose a willing creature within 5 feet of yourself that is Large or smaller. You move the creature with you until the end of your turn. The creature's movement doesn't provoke Opportunity Attacks.

classFeature.name: Self-Restoration
entries: Through sheer force of will, you can remove one of the following conditions from yourself at the end of each of your turns: {@condition Charmed|Ishiir}, {@condition Frightened|Ishiir}, or {@condition Poisoned|Ishiir}.
In addition, forgoing food and drink doesn't give you levels of Exhaustion.

classFeature.name: Monastic Tradition feature
entries: You gain one feature granted by your Monastic Tradition.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: {@variantrule Proficiency|Ishiir} Versatility
entries: When you gain the Ability Score Improvement feature from your class, you can also replace one of your skill proficiencies with a skill {@variantrule Proficiency|Ishiir} offered by your class at 1st level (the {@variantrule Proficiency|Ishiir} you replace needn't be from the class).
This change represents one of your skills atrophying as you focus on a different skill.

classFeature.name: Tongue of the Sun and Moon
entries: You learn to touch the ki of other minds so that you understand all spoken languages. Moreover, any creature that can understand a language can understand what you say.

classFeature.name: Deflect Energy
entries: Wou can now use your Deflect Attacks feature against attacks that deal any damage type, not just Bludgeoning, Piercing, or Slashing.

classFeature.name: Diamond Soul
entries: Your mastery of ki grants you {@variantrule Proficiency|Ishiir} in all {@variantrule Saving Throw|Ishiir}s.
Additionally, whenever you make a {@variantrule Saving Throw|Ishiir} and fail, you can spend 1 ki point to reroll it and take the second result.

classFeature.name: Timeless Body
entries: Your ki sustains you so that you suffer none of the frailty of old age, and you can't be aged magically. You can still die of old age, however. In addition, you no longer need food or water.

classFeature.name: Perfect Focus
entries: When you roll Initiative and don't use Uncanny Metabolism, you regain expended Focus Points until you have 4 if you have 3 or fewer.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: {@variantrule Proficiency|Ishiir} Versatility
entries: When you gain the Ability Score Improvement feature from your class, you can also replace one of your skill proficiencies with a skill {@variantrule Proficiency|Ishiir} offered by your class at 1st level (the {@variantrule Proficiency|Ishiir} you replace needn't be from the class).
This change represents one of your skills atrophying as you focus on a different skill.

classFeature.name: Monastic Tradition feature
entries: You gain one feature granted by your Monastic Tradition.

classFeature.name: Superior Defense
entries: At the start of your turn, you can expend 3 Focus Points to bolster yourself against harm for 1 minute or until you have the {@condition Incapacitated|Ishiir} condition. During that time, you have {@variantrule Resistance|Ishiir} to all damage except Force damage.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: {@variantrule Proficiency|Ishiir} Versatility
entries: When you gain the Ability Score Improvement feature from your class, you can also replace one of your skill proficiencies with a skill {@variantrule Proficiency|Ishiir} offered by your class at 1st level (the {@variantrule Proficiency|Ishiir} you replace needn't be from the class).
This change represents one of your skills atrophying as you focus on a different skill.

classFeature.name: Perfect Self
entries: You have developed your body and mind to new heights. Your Dexterity and Wisdom scores increase by 4, to a maximum of 24.

subclassFeature.name: Way of the Ascendant Dragon
entries: The dragon god Bahamut is known to travel the Material Plane in the guise of a young monk, and legend says that he founded the first monastery of the Way of the Ascendant Dragon in this guise. The fundamental teaching of this tradition holds that by emulating dragons, a monk becomes a more integrated part of the world and its magic. By altering their spirit to resonate with draconic might, monks who follow this tradition augment their prowess in battle, bolster their allies, and can even soar through the air on draconic wings. But all this power is in service of a greater goal: achieving a spiritual unity with the essence of the Material Plane.
As a follower of the Way of the Ascendant Dragon, you decide how you unlocked the power of dragons within yourself. The Ascendant Dragon Origin table offers a number of possibilities.

entries.caption: Ascendant Dragon Origin
rows: You honed your abilities by aligning your spirit with a dragon's world-altering power.
A dragon personally took an active role in shaping your inner energy.
You studied at a monastery that traces its teachings back centuries or more to a single dragon's instruction, or one that is devoted to a dragon god.
You spent long stretches meditating in the region around an ancient dragon's lair, absorbing that lair's ambient magic.
You found a scroll written in Draconic that contained inspiring new techniques.
After a dream featuring a five-handed dragonborn, you awoke with the mystical breath of dragons.

subclassFeature.name: Breath of the Dragon
entries: You can channel destructive waves of energy, like those created by the dragons you emulate. When you take the {@action Attack|Ishiir} action on your turn, you can replace one of the attacks with an exhalation of draconic energy in either a 20-foot cone or a 40-foot line that is 5 feet wide (your choice). Choose a damage type: acid, cold, fire, lightning, or poison. Each creature in that area must make a Dexterity {@variantrule Saving Throw|Ishiir} against your ki save DC, taking damage of the chosen type equal to two rolls of your Martial Arts die on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.
At 11th level, the damage of this feature increases to three rolls of your Martial Arts die.

You can use this feature a number of times equal to your {@variantrule Proficiency|Ishiir} bonus, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|Ishiir}. While you have no uses available, you can spend 2 ki points to use this feature again.

subclassFeature.name: Draconic Disciple
entries: You can channel draconic power to magnify your presence and imbue your unarmed strikes with the essence of a dragon's breath. You gain the following benefits:

items.name: Draconic Presence
items.entry: If you fail a Charisma ({@skill Intimidation}) or Charisma ({@skill Persuasion}) check, you can use your reaction to reroll the check, as you tap into the mighty presence of dragons. Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a {@variantrule Short Rest|Ishiir} or a {@variantrule Long Rest|Ishiir}.

items.name: Draconic Strike
items.entry: When you damage a target with an unarmed strike, you can change the damage type to acid, cold, fire, lightning, or poison.

items.name: Tongue of Dragons
items.entry: You learn to speak, read, and write {@language Draconic} or one other language of your choice.

subclassFeature.name: Wings Unfurled
entries: When you use your Step of the Wind, you can unfurl spectral draconic wings from your back that vanish at the end of your turn. While the wings exist, you have a {@variantrule Fly Speed|Ishiir} equal to your {@variantrule Speed|Ishiir}.

You can use this feature a number of times equal to your {@variantrule Proficiency|Ishiir} bonus, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|Ishiir}. While you have no uses available, you can spend 3 ki points to use this feature again.

subclassFeature.name: Aspect of the Wyrm
entries: The power of your draconic spirit now radiates from you, warding your allies or inspiring fear in your enemies. As a bonus action, you can create an aura of draconic power that radiates 10 feet from you for 1 minute. For the duration, you gain one of the following effects of your choice:

items.name: Frightful Presence
items.entry: When you create this aura, and as a bonus action on subsequent turns, you can choose a creature within the aura. The target must succeed on a Wisdom {@variantrule Saving Throw|Ishiir} against your ki save DC or become {@condition Frightened|Ishiir} of you for 1 minute. The target can repeat the {@variantrule Saving Throw|Ishiir} at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a successful save.

items.name: Resistance
items.entry: Choose a damage type when you activate this aura: acid, cold, fire, lightning, or poison. You and your allies within the aura have {@variantrule Resistance|Ishiir} to that damage.

entries: Once you create this aura, you can't create it again until you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|Ishiir}, unless you expend 3 ki points to create it again.

subclassFeature.name: Ascendant Aspect
entries: Your draconic spirit reaches its peak. You gain the following benefits:

items.name: Augment Breath
items.entry: When you use your Breath of the Dragon, you can spend 1 ki point to augment its shape and power. The exhalation of draconic energy becomes either a 60-foot cone or a 120-foot line that is 5 feet wide (your choice), and each creature in that area takes damage equal to four rolls of your Martial Arts die on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

items.name: Blindsight
items.entry: You gain {@sense blindsight} out to 10 feet. Within that range, you can effectively see anything that isn't behind total cover, even if you're {@condition Blinded|Ishiir} or in darkness. Moreover, you can see an {@condition Invisible|Ishiir} creature within that range, unless the creature successfully hides from you.

items.name: Explosive Fury
items.entry: When you activate your Aspect of the Wyrm, draconic fury explodes from you. Choose any number of creatures you can see in your aura. Each of those creatures must succeed on a Dexterity {@variantrule Saving Throw|Ishiir} against your ki save DC or take {@damage 3d10} acid, cold, fire, lightning, or poison damage (your choice).

subclassFeature.name: Way of the Astral Self
entries: A monk who follows the Way of the Astral Self believes their body is an illusion. They see their ki as a representation of their true form, an astral self. This astral self has the capacity to be a force of order or disorder, with some monasteries training students to use their power to protect the weak and other instructing aspirants in how to manifest their true selves in service to the mighty.

entries.subclassFeature: Forms of Your Astral Self|Monk|Ishiir|Astral Self|Ishiir|3
Arms of the Astral Self|Monk|Ishiir|Astral Self|Ishiir|3

subclassFeature.name: Arms of the Astral Self
entries: Your mastery of your ki allows you to summon a portion of your astral self. As a bonus action, you can spend 1 ki point to summon the arms of your astral self. Alternatively, you can spend this ki point as part of the same Bonus Action you used for another Monk feature. When you do so, each creature of your choice that you can see within 10 feet of you must succeed on a Dexterity {@variantrule Saving Throw|Ishiir} or take force damage equal to two rolls of your Martial Arts die. At 11th level, the damage of this feature increases to three rolls of your Martial Arts die.

For 10 minutes, these spectral arms hover near your shoulders or surround your arms (your choice). You determine the arms' appearance, and they vanish early if you are {@condition Incapacitated|Ishiir} or die.
While the spectral arms are present, you gain the following benefits:

items: You can use your Wisdom modifier in place of your Strength modifier when making Strength checks and Strength {@variantrule Saving Throw|Ishiir}s.
You can use the spectral arms to make unarmed strikes.
When you make an unarmed strike with the arms on your turn, your reach for it is 5 feet greater than normal.
The unarmed strikes you make with the arms can use your Wisdom modifier in place of your Strength or Dexterity modifier for the attack and damage rolls, and their damage type is force.
When you use Deflect Attack, you add your Wisdom modifier to both the amount of damage you reduce and the amount of damage you deal.

subclassFeature.name: Forms of Your Astral Self
entries: The astral self is a translucent embodiment of the monk's soul. As a result, an astral self can reflect aspects of a monk's background, ideals, flaws, and bonds, and an astral self doesn't necessarily look anything like the monk. For example, the astral self of a lanky human might be reminiscent of a minotaur-the strength of which the monk feels within. Similarly, an orc monk might manifest gossamer arms and a delicate visage, representing the gentle beauty of the orc's soul. Each astral self is unique, and some of the monks of this monastic tradition are known more for the appearance of their astral self than for their physical appearance.

When choosing this path, consider the quirks that define your monk. Are you obsessed with something? Are you driven by justice or a selfish desire? Any of these motivations could manifest in the form of your astral self.

subclassFeature.name: Visage of the Astral Self
entries: You can summon the visage of your astral self. As a bonus action, or as part of the bonus action you take to activate Arms of the Astral Self, you can spend 1 ki point to summon this visage for 10 minutes. It vanishes early if you are {@condition Incapacitated|Ishiir} or die.
The spectral visage covers your face like a helmet or mask. You determine its appearance.
While the spectral visage is present, you gain the following benefits.

entries.name: Astral Sight
entries: You can see normally in darkness, both magical and nonmagical, to a distance of 120 feet.

entries.name: Wisdom of the Spirit
entries: You have {@variantrule Advantage|Ishiir} on Wisdom ({@skill Insight}) and Charisma ({@skill Intimidation}) checks.

entries.name: Word of the Spirit
entries: When you speak, you can direct your words to a creature of your choice that you can see within 60 feet of you, making it so only that creature can hear you. Alternatively, you can amplify your voice so that all creatures within 600 feet can hear you.

subclassFeature.name: Body of the Astral Self
entries: When you have both your astral arms and visage summoned, you can cause the body of your astral self to appear (no action required). This spectral body covers your physical form like a suit of armor, connecting with the arms and visage. You determine its appearance.
While the spectral body is present, you gain the following benefits.

entries.name: Improved Deflect Attack
entries: The damage dealt by your Deflect Attack increases to three rolls of your Martial Arts die and you can change the damage type to force damage.

entries.name: Empowered Arms
entries: Once on each of your turns when you hit a target with the Arms of the Astral Self, you can deal extra damage to the target equal to your Martial Arts die.

subclassFeature.name: Awakened Astral Self
entries: Your connection to your astral self is complete, allowing you to unleash its full potential. As a bonus action, you can spend 3 ki points to summon the arms, visage, and body of your astral self and awaken it for 10 minutes. Alternatively, you can spend these ki points as part of the same Bonus Action you used for another Monk feature. This awakening ends early if you are {@condition Incapacitated|Ishiir} or die.
The cost is reduced by 1 each if you have currently summoned your astral arms and your astral visage.
While your astral self is awakened, you gain the following benefits.

entries.name: Armor of the Spirit
entries: You gain a +2 bonus to Armor Class.

entries.name: Astral Barrage
entries: Whenever you use the Extra Attack feature to attack twice, you can instead attack three times if all the attacks are made with your astral arms.

subclassFeature.name: Way of the Drunken Master
entries: The Way of the Drunken Master teaches its students to move with the jerky, unpredictable movements of a drunkard. A drunken master sways, tottering on unsteady feet, to present what seems like an incompetent combatant who proves frustrating to engage. The drunken master's erratic stumbles conceal a carefully executed dance of blocks, parries, advances, attacks, and retreats.

A drunken master often enjoys playing the fool to bring gladness to the despondent or to demonstrate humility to the arrogant, but when battle is joined, the drunken master can be a maddening, masterful foe.

subclassFeature.name: Bonus Proficiencies
entries: You gain {@variantrule Proficiency|Ishiir} in the {@skill Performance} skill if you don't already have it. Your martial arts technique mixes combat training with the precision of a dancer and the antics of a jester. You also gain {@variantrule Proficiency|Ishiir} with {@item brewer's supplies|Ishiir} if you don't already have it.

subclassFeature.name: Drunken Technique
entries: You learn how to twist and turn quickly as part of your Flurry of Blows. Whenever you use Flurry of Blows, you gain the benefit of the {@action Disengage|Ishiir} action, and your {@variantrule Speed|Ishiir} increases by 10 feet until the end of the current turn.

subclassFeature.name: Tipsy Sway
entries: You can move in sudden, swaying ways. You gain the following benefits.

subclassFeature.name: Leap to Your Feet
entries: When you're {@condition Prone|Ishiir}, you can stand up by spending 5 feet of movement, rather than half your {@variantrule Speed|Ishiir}.

subclassFeature.name: Redirect Attack
entries: When a creature hits you with an {@variantrule Attack Roll|Ishiir}, you can spend 1 ki point as a reaction to cause that attack to target another creature of your choice, other than the attacker, that you can see within 5 feet of you.

Once you use this feature, you canâ€™t use it again until you finish a {@variantrule Short Rest|Ishiir} or a {@variantrule Long Rest|Ishiir}. Alternatively, you can spend 2 ki points to regain a use of this feature (no action required).

subclassFeature.name: Drunkard's Luck
entries: You always seem to get a lucky bounce at the right moment. When you make an {@variantrule Ability Check|Ishiir}, an {@variantrule Attack Roll|Ishiir}, or a {@variantrule Saving Throw|Ishiir} and have {@variantrule Disadvantage|Ishiir} on the roll, you can spend 2 ki points to cancel the {@variantrule Disadvantage|Ishiir} for that roll.

subclassFeature.name: Incalculable Sway
entries: No {@variantrule Attack Roll|Ishiir} can have {@variantrule Advantage|Ishiir} against you when you are under the effect of Patient Defense.
Additionally, whenever an {@variantrule Attack Roll|Ishiir} misses you, you can move 10 feet in any direction without provoking Attacks of Opportunity.

subclassFeature.name: Way of the Four Elements
entries: You follow a monastic tradition that teaches you to harness the elements. When you focus your ki, you can align yourself with the forces of creation and bend the Four Elements to your will, using them as an extension of your body. Some members of this tradition dedicate themselves to a single element, but others weave the elements together.
Many monks of this tradition tattoo their bodies with representations of their ki powers, commonly imagined as coiling dragons, but also as phoenixes, fish, plants, mountains, and cresting waves.

subclassFeature.name: Disciple of the Elements
entries: You learn magical disciplines that harness the power of the Four Elements. A discipline requires you to spend ki points each time you use it.
You know the Elemental Attunement discipline and two other elemental disciplines of your choice. You learn one additional elemental discipline of your choice at 6th, 11th, and 17th level.
Whenever you learn a new elemental discipline, you can also replace one elemental discipline that you already know with a different discipline.

When you use an elemental discipline to cast a spell that scales with the level of the spell slot it is used with, you can spend additional ki points to treat the spell as cast at a higher level. You spend 1 ki point for each level above the original and the resulting level of the spell cannot be greater than your {@variantrule Proficiency|Ishiir} bonus.
When you use an elemental discipline as an action, you can also make one unarmed strike as a bonus action.

entries.name: Casting Elemental Spells
entries: Some elemental disciplines allow you to cast spells. See {@book chapter 10|PHB|10} of the Player's Handbook for the general rules of spellcasting. To cast one of these spells, you use its casting time and other rules, but you don't need to provide material components for it.

Once you reach 5th level in this class, you can spend additional ki points to increase the level of an elemental discipline spell that you cast, provided that the spell has an enhanced effect at a higher level, as {@spell burning hands|Ishiir} does. The spell's level increases by 1 for each additional ki point you spend. For example, if you are a 5th-level monk and use Sweeping Cinder Strike to cast {@spell burning hands|Ishiir}, you can spend 3 ki points to cast it as a 2nd-level spell (the discipline's base cost of 2 ki points plus 1).

The maximum number of ki points you can spend to cast a spell in this way (including its base ki point cost and any additional ki points you spend to increase its level) is determined by your monk level, as shown in the Spells and Ki Points table. You may spend up to 3 ki points; this increases to 4 ki points at 9th level, 5 at 13th level, and 6 at 17th level.

subclassFeature.name: Elemental Disciplines
entries: The elemental disciplines are presented in alphabetical order. If a discipline requires a level, you must be the level in this class to learn the discipline.

entries.name: Clench of the North Wind (6th Level Required)
Flames of the Phoenix (11th Level Required)
Gong of the Summit (6th Level Required)
River of Hungry Flame (17th Level Required)
Wave of Rolling Earth (17th Level Required)

subclassFeature.name: Extra Elemental Discipline
entries: You learn one additional elemental discipline of your choice. You should know 2 elemental disciplines, as well as Elemental Attunement.
Whenever you learn a new elemental discipline, you can also replace one elemental discipline that you already know with a different discipline.

subclassFeature.name: Elemental Conversion
entries: You can replace the damage of any of your elemental disciplines with that of another elemental discipline you know when you use them.

subclassFeature.name: Extra Elemental Discipline
entries: You learn one additional elemental discipline of your choice. You should know 3 elemental disciplines, as well as Elemental Attunement.
Whenever you learn a new elemental discipline, you can also replace one elemental discipline that you already know with a different discipline.

subclassFeature.name: Elemental Focus
entries: You can choose two of your elemental disciplines and reduce their ki cost by 1 (minimum of 1). You change your choices whenever you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|Ishiir}.

subclassFeature.name: Extra Elemental Discipline
entries: You learn one additional elemental discipline of your choice. You should know 4 elemental disciplines, as well as Elemental Attunement.
Whenever you learn a new elemental discipline, you can also replace one elemental discipline that you already know with a different discipline.

subclassFeature.name: Elemental Overcharge
entries: You can cast a spell gained through an elemental discipline as a 9th level spell, without expending any additional ki points.
You cannot use this feature again until you have finished a {@variantrule Long Rest|Ishiir}.

subclassFeature.name: Way of the Kensei
entries: Monks of the Way of the Kensei train relentlessly with their weapons, to the point where the weapon becomes an extension of the body. Founded on a mastery of sword fighting, the tradition has expanded to include many different weapons.

A kensei sees a weapon in much the same way a calligrapher or painter regards a pen or brush. Whatever the weapon, the kensei views it as a tool used to express the beauty and precision of the martial arts. That such mastery makes a kensei a peerless warrior is but a side effect of intense devotion, practice, and study.

subclassFeature.name: Path of the Kensei
entries: Your special martial arts training leads you to master the use of certain weapons. This path also includes instruction in the deft strokes of calligraphy or painting. You gain the following benefits.

entries.name: Kensei Weapons
entries: Choose two weapons that do not have the special or heavy properties. You are proficient in these weapons and they count as monk weapons for you.
Whenever you make an unarmed attack, you can attack with one of these weapons instead if you are currently wielding them.
You can choose two additional weapons when you reach the levels 6, 11, and 17 in this class, following the same criteria.

entries.name: Way of the Brush
entries: You gain {@variantrule Proficiency|Ishiir} with your choice of {@item calligrapher's supplies|Ishiir} or {@item painter's supplies|Ishiir}.

subclassFeature.name: Fighting Style
entries: Choose one of the fighting styles available to the fighter class. You can't take the same Fighting Style option more than once, even if you get to choose again.

subclassFeature.name: One with the Blade
entries: You extend your ki into your kensei weapons, granting you the following benefits.

entries.name: Magic Kensei Weapons
entries: Your attacks with your kensei weapons count as magical for the purpose of overcoming {@variantrule Resistance|Ishiir} and {@variantrule Immunity|Ishiir} to nonmagical attacks and damage.

entries.name: Deft Riposte
entries: When you spend Ki on your Deflect Attack feature, you can attack with a monk weapon you are currently wielding instead of forcing the target to make a Dexterity {@variantrule Saving Throw|Ishiir}, provided the target is within your reach.

subclassFeature.name: Unerring Accuracy
entries: Your mastery of weapons grants you extraordinary accuracy. If you miss with an {@variantrule Attack Roll|Ishiir} using a monk weapon on your turn, you can reroll it and take the second result. You can use this feature only once on each of your turns.

subclassFeature.name: Kensai Kai
entries: You learn to infuse your monk weapons with some of your Ki, making them even more deadly. Your critical range with your monk weapons increases by 1.
Additionally, when you deal damage with a monk weapon, you can spend 1 Ki Point to deal additional damage equal to a roll of your Martial Arts die.

subclassFeature.name: Way of the Long Death
entries: Monks of the Way of the Long Death are obsessed with the meaning and mechanics of dying. They capture creatures and prepare elaborate experiments to capture, record, and understand the moments of their demise. They use this knowledge to guide their understanding of martial arts, yielding a deadly fighting style.

subclassFeature.name: Touch of Death
entries: Your study of death allows you to extract vitality from another creature as it nears its demise. When you reduce a creature within 10 feet of you to 0 hit points, you gain temporary hit points equal to your Wisdom modifier + your monk level (minimum of 1 temporary hit point).

subclassFeature.name: Hour of Reaping
entries: You gain the ability to unsettle or terrify those around you as an action, for your soul has been touched by the shadow of death. When you take this action, each creature within 30 feet of you that can see you must succeed on a Wisdom {@variantrule Saving Throw|Ishiir} or be {@condition Frightened|Ishiir} of you until the end of your next turn.
You can also this feature when you gain temporary hit points through Touch of Death (no action required).

subclassFeature.name: Mastery of Death
entries: You use your familiarity with death to escape its grasp. When you are reduced to 0 hit points and don't die outright, you can expend 1 ki point (no action required) to have 1 hit point instead.

subclassFeature.name: Touch of the Long Death
entries: Your touch can channel the energy of death into a creature. As an action, you touch one creature within 5 feet of you, and you expend 1 to 10 ki points. The target must make a Constitution {@variantrule Saving Throw|Ishiir}, and it takes {@damage 2d10} necrotic damage per ki point spent on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. A creature that failed this {@variantrule Saving Throw|Ishiir} has to repeat the {@variantrule Saving Throw|Ishiir} at the end of each of its turn. On a failure, it takes necrotic damage equal to your monk level. Until it succeeds, the creature cannot benefit from healing.

subclassFeature.name: Way of Mercy
entries: Monks of the Way of Mercy learn to manipulate the life force of others to bring aid to those in need. They are wandering physicians to the poor and hurt. However, to those beyond their help, they bring a swift end as an act of mercy.

Those who follow the Way of Mercy might be members of a religious order, administering to the needy and making grim choices rooted in reality rather than idealism. Some might be gentle-voiced healers, beloved by their communities, while others might be masked bringers of macabre mercies.
The walkers of this way usually don robes with deep cowls, and they often conceal their faces with masks, presenting themselves as the faceless bringers of life and death.

subclassFeature.name: Hand of Harm
entries: You use your ki to inflict wounds. When you hit a creature with an unarmed strike, you can spend 1 ki point to deal extra necrotic damage equal to one roll of your Martial Arts die + your Wisdom modifier. You can use this feature only once per turn.

subclassFeature.name: Hand of Healing
entries: Your mystical touch can mend wounds. As an action, you can spend 1 ki point to touch a creature and restore a number of hit points equal to a roll of your Martial Arts die + your Wisdom modifier.
When you use your Flurry of Blows, you can replace one of the unarmed strikes with a use of this feature without spending a ki point for the healing.

subclassFeature.name: Implements of Mercy
entries: You gain {@variantrule Proficiency|Ishiir} in the {@skill Insight} and {@skill Medicine} skills, and you gain {@variantrule Proficiency|Ishiir} with the {@item herbalism kit|Ishiir}.
You also gain a special mask, which you often wear when using the features of this subclass. You determine its appearance, or generate it randomly by rolling on the Merciful Mask table.

entries.caption: Merciful Mask
rows: Raven
Blank and white
Crying visage
Laughing visage
Skull
Butterfly

subclassFeature.name: Physician's Touch
entries: You can administer even greater cures with a touch, and if you feel it's necessary, you can use your knowledge to cause harm.

When you use Hand of Healing, you can also end one of the following conditions on the creature you heal or remove one disease affecting them: {@condition Blinded|Ishiir}, {@condition Deafened|Ishiir}, {@condition Paralyzed|Ishiir}, {@condition Poisoned|Ishiir}, or {@condition Stunned|Ishiir}.

When you use Hand of Harm on a creature, you can also force that creature to make a Constitution {@variantrule Saving Throw|Ishiir} or have the {@condition Poisoned|Ishiir} condition until the end of your next turn.

subclassFeature.name: Flurry of Healing and Harm
entries: You can now mete out a flurry of comfort and hurt. When you use Flurry of Blows, you can now replace each of the unarmed strikes with a use of your Hand of Healing, without spending ki points for the healing.

In addition, when you make an unarmed strike with Flurry of Blows, you can use Hand of Harm with that strike without spending the ki point for Hand of Harm. You can still use Hand of Harm only once per turn.

subclassFeature.name: Hand of Ultimate Mercy
entries: Your mastery of life energy opens the door to the ultimate mercy. As an action, you can touch the corpse of a creature that died within the past 24 hours and expend 5 ki points. The creature then returns to life, regaining a number of hit points equal to {@dice 4d10} + your Wisdom modifier. If the creature died while subject to any of the following conditions, it revives with them removed: {@condition Blinded|Ishiir}, {@condition Deafened|Ishiir}, {@condition Paralyzed|Ishiir}, {@condition Poisoned|Ishiir}, and {@condition Stunned|Ishiir}.
Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|Ishiir}.

subclassFeature.name: Way of the Open Hand
entries: Monks of the Way of the Open Hand are the ultimate masters of martial arts combat, whether armed or unarmed. They learn techniques to push and trip their opponents, manipulate ki to heal damage to their bodies, and practice advanced meditation that can protect them from harm.

subclassFeature.name: Open Hand Technique
entries: You can manipulate your enemy's ki when you harness your own. Whenever you hit a creature with one of the attacks granted by your Flurry of Blows, you can impose one of the following effects on that target.

items: It must succeed on a Dexterity {@variantrule Saving Throw|Ishiir} or be knocked {@condition Prone|Ishiir}.
It must make a Strength {@variantrule Saving Throw|Ishiir}. If it fails, you can push it up to 15 feet away from you.
It must make a Constitution {@variantrule Saving Throw|Ishiir}. If it fails, it can't take reactions until the end of your next turn.

subclassFeature.name: Wholeness of Body
entries: You gain the ability to heal yourself. As an action, you can regain hit points equal to three times your monk level. You must finish a {@variantrule Short Rest|Ishiir} or a {@variantrule Long Rest|Ishiir} before you can use this feature again.

subclassFeature.name: Fleet Step
entries: When you take a Bonus Action other than Step of the Wind, you can also use Step of the Wind immediately after that Bonus Action.

subclassFeature.name: Quivering Palm
entries: You gain the ability to set up lethal vibrations in someone's body. When you hit a creature with an Unarmed Strike, you can expend 4 Focus Points to start these imperceptible vibrations, which last for a number of days equal to your Monk level. The vibrations are harmless unless you take an action to end them. Alternatively, when you take the Attack action on your turn, you can forgo one of the attacks to end the vibrations. To end them, you and the target must be on the same plane of existence. When you end them, the target must make a Constitution {@variantrule Saving Throw|Ishiir}, taking {@damage 10d12} Force damage on a failed save or half as much damage on a successful one.
You can have only one creature under the effect of this feature at a time. You can end the vibrations harmlessly (no action required).

subclassFeature.name: Way of Shadow
entries: Monks of the Way of Shadow follow a tradition that values stealth and subterfuge. These monks might be called ninjas or shadowdancers, and they serve as spies and assassins. Sometimes the members of a ninja monastery are family members, forming a clan sworn to secrecy about their arts and missions. Other monasteries are more like thieves' guilds, hiring out their services to nobles, rich merchants, or anyone else who can pay their fees. Regardless of their methods, the heads of these monasteries expect the unquestioning obedience of their students.

subclassFeature.name: Shadow Arts
entries: You have learned to draw on the power of the Shadowfell, gaining the following benefits.

items.name: Darkness.
items.entry: You can expend 1 Focus Point to cast the {@spell Darkness|Ishiir} spell without spell components. You can see within the spell's area when you cast it with this feature. While the spell persists, you can move its area of {@spell Darkness|Ishiir} to a space within 60 feet of yourself at the start of each of your turns.

items.name: Darkvision.
items.entry: You gain {@sense Darkvision} with a range of 60 feet. If you already have {@sense Darkvision}, its range increases by 60 feet.

items.name: Shadowy Figments.
items.entry: You know the {@spell Minor Illusion|Ishiir} spell. Wisdom is your spellcasting ability for it.

items.name: Silent Shadow.
items.entry: You can can expend 2 Ki Points to cast the {@spell Pass without Trace|Ishiir} without spell components.

subclassFeature.name: Shadow Step
entries: You gain the ability to step from one shadow into another. When you are in dim light or darkness, as a bonus action you can teleport up to 60 feet to an unoccupied space you can see that is also in dim light or darkness. You then have {@variantrule Advantage|Ishiir} on the first melee attack you make before the end of the turn.

subclassFeature.name: Improved Shadow Step
entries: You can draw on your Shadowfell connection to empower your teleportation. When you use your Shadow Step, you can expend 1 Ki Point to remove the requirement that you must start and end in Dim Light or Darkness for that use of the feature. As part of this Bonus Action, you can make an Unarmed Strike immediately after you teleport.

subclassFeature.name: Cloak of Shadows
entries: As a {@action Magic|Ishiir} action while entirely within Dim Light or Darkness, you can expend 3 Ki Points to shroud yourself with shadows for 1 minute, until you have the {@condition Incapacitated|Ishiir} condition, or until you end your turn in Bright Light. While shrouded by these shadows, you gain the following benefits.

items.name: Invisibility.
items.entry: You have the {@condition Invisible|Ishiir} condition.

items.name: Partially Incorporeal.
items.entry: You can move through occupied spaces as if they were {@quickref Difficult Terrain||3}. If you end your turn in such a space, you are shunted to the last unoccupied space you were in.

items.name: Shadow Flurry.
items.entry: You can use your Flurry of Blows without expending any Ki Points. When you use your Improved Shadow Step, you can use Flurry of Blows as part of the same Bonus Action.

subclassFeature.name: Way of the Soul Knife
entries: {@i Transcribed on 2018-10-13. [Square bracketed text] denotes transcriber's annotations.}

Monks of the Way of the Soul Knife are deadly assassins and bounty hunters. They use their psionic talents to manifest psionic blades that tear through their enemies' bodies and psychic auras. Their talents extend beyond combat, as their ability to perceive auras allows them to track down foes and see through their deceptions.

subclassFeature.name: Psychic Slash
entries: You can spend 1 ki point to channel ki into your attacks you augment your soul knives to inflict devastating psionic attacks.
Whenever you hit a creature with one of the attacks granted by your Flurry of Blows and that attack inflicts psychic damage, you can impose one of the following effects on the target:

entries.name: Life Drain
entries: You gain temporary hit points equal to half the damage your attack deals.

entries.name: Invoke Terror
entries: The target must succeed on a Wisdom {@variantrule Saving Throw|Ishiir} or become {@condition Frightened|Ishiir} of you until the end of your next turn.

entries.name: Invoke Wrath
entries: The target suffers {@variantrule Disadvantage|Ishiir} on all {@variantrule Attack Roll|Ishiir}s against targets other than you until the end of your next turn.

entries.name: Astral Slide
entries: You teleport the target up to 10 feet to a destination you can see.

entries.name: Synaptic Overload
entries: The target has to make an Intelligence {@variantrule Saving Throw|Ishiir} or take double damage the next time it takes psychic damage from you before the end of your next turn.

subclassFeature.name: Soul Knife
entries: You can use your psionic energy to manifest blades that disrupt your foes' minds.
Your unarmed strikes deal your choice of psychic, piercing, slashing, or bludgeoning damage each time you hit.
In addition, you can expend a Ki Point to increase the reach of your unarmed strikes by 30 feet until the end of your current turn.

subclassFeature.name: Aura Sight
entries: You gain the ability to perceive the auras of other creatures.

As an action, select a creature that you can see. That creature makes a Wisdom {@variantrule Saving Throw|Ishiir}, though it has no knowledge that you forced it to attempt this {@variantrule Saving Throw|Ishiir}. On a failed save, you learn if the creature shares any aspects of its alignment with you, its current hit points, and its current attitude and intentions toward you or one other creature, object, or location of your choice. In addition, for the next 24 hours or until you use this ability again, you can use an action to determine the creature's distance and direction from you.
If a creature succeeds on its {@variantrule Saving Throw|Ishiir} against this ability, you cannot use this ability against that creature again until you complete a {@variantrule Long Rest|Ishiir}.

subclassFeature.name: Psychic Mastery
entries: You gain {@variantrule Resistance|Ishiir} to psychic damage and your features ignore {@variantrule Resistance|Ishiir} to psychic damage.

subclassFeature.name: Spectral Blade Dance
entries: As an action, you can spend 6 ki points to and choose up to seven creatures you can see within 30 ft. Make a melee attack against each target. On a hit, a target takes {@damage 5d12} psychic damage and you can use one effect from your Psychic Slash feature against it (no additional ki required).

subclassFeature.name: Way of the Sun Soul
entries: Monks of the Way of the Sun Soul learn to channel their life energy into searing bolts of light. They teach that meditation can unlock the ability to unleash the indomitable light shed by the soul of every living creature.

subclassFeature.name: Radiant Sun Bolt
entries: You can hurl searing bolts of magical radiance.
When you make an Unarmed Strike, you can replace it with a ranged weapon attack with a range of 60 feet, which deals radiant damage equal to your Unarmed Strike.

subclassFeature.name: Hand of Light
entries: Your Unarmed Strikes deal your choice of bludgeoning or radiant damage.

subclassFeature.name: Searing Sunburst
entries: You gain the ability to create an orb of light that erupts into a devastating explosion. As an action, you magically create an orb and hurl it at a point you choose within 150 feet, where it erupts into a sphere of radiant light for a brief but deadly instant.

Each creature in that 20-foot-radius sphere must succeed on a Constitution {@variantrule Saving Throw|Ishiir} or take {@damage 2d6} radiant damage. A creature doesn't need to make the save if the creature is behind total cover that is opaque.
You can increase the sphere's damage by spending ki points. Each point you spend, to a maximum of 3, increases the damage by {@dice 2d6}.

subclassFeature.name: Sun Shield
entries: You can expend 4 Ki Points as an action and become wreathed in a luminous, magical aura for 10 minutes. You shed bright light in a 30-foot radius and dim light for an additional 30 feet. This light counts as sunlight. You can extinguish or restore the light as a bonus action.
If a creature hits you with a melee attack while this light shines, it takes radiant damage equal to a roll of your Martial Arts die.

subclassFeature.name: Inner Sun
entries: You can expend 1 to 10 Ki Points as an action and bathe the area in a 30-foot Emanation in a blinding light. Each creature of your choice in the area has to make a Constitution {@variantrule Saving Throw|Ishiir}. On a failed save, a target takes {@damage 1d10} radiant damage per Ki Point spent and is {@condition Blinded|Ishiir} until the end of your next turn. On a successful save, it takes half as much damage and isn't blinded.

subclassFeature.name: Way of Tranquility
entries: Monks of the Way of Tranquility see violence as a last resort. They use diplomacy, mercy, and understanding to resolve conflicts. If pushed, though, they are capable warriors who can bring an end to the unjust or cruel folk who refuse to listen to reason. When adventuring, these monks make excellent diplomats. They are also skilled in the healing arts, and can preserve their allies in the face of daunting foes.

subclassFeature.name: Healing Hands
entries: Your mystical touch can heal wounds. You have a pool of magical healing power that replenishes when you take a {@variantrule Long Rest|Ishiir}. With that pool, you can restore a total number of hit points equal to your monk level Ã— 5.
As an action, you can touch a creature and draw power from the pool to restore a number of hit points to that creature, up to the maximum amount remaining in the pool.

Instead of healing the creature, you can expend 5 hit points from your pool of healing to cure the target of one disease or neutralize one poison affecting it. You can cure multiple diseases and neutralize multiple poisons with a single use of Healing Hands, expending hit points separately for each one.
When you use your Flurry of Blows, you can replace one of the unarmed strikes with a use of this feature.
This feature has no effect on undead and constructs.

subclassFeature.name: Path of Tranquility
entries: You can become an island of calm in even the most chaotic of situations. With this feature, you can cast the {@spell sanctuary|Ishiir} spell on yourself, no material component required, and it lasts up to 8 hours. Its {@variantrule Saving Throw|Ishiir} DC equals 8 + your {@variantrule Proficiency|Ishiir} bonus + your Wisdom modifier. A creature that succeeds on the save is {@variantrule Immunity|Ishiir|Immune} to this effect for 1 hour.
Once you cast the spell in this way, you can't do so again for 1 minute.

subclassFeature.name: Emissary of Peace
entries: You gain the ability to diffuse violent situations. Whenever you make a Charisma check to calm violent emotions or to counsel peace, you have {@variantrule Advantage|Ishiir} on the roll. You must make this entreaty in good faith; it doesn't apply if {@variantrule Proficiency|Ishiir} in the {@skill Deception} or {@skill Intimidation} skill applies to your check.
You also gain {@variantrule Proficiency|Ishiir} in the {@skill Performance} or {@skill Persuasion} skill (choose one).

subclassFeature.name: Serene Mind
entries: You make Wisdom {@variantrule Saving Throw|Ishiir}s with {@variantrule Advantage|Ishiir} and when you use Self-Restoration, you can also remove the {@condition Confused|Ishiir} condition.

subclassFeature.name: Anger of a Gentle Soul
entries: You gain the ability to visit vengeance on someone who fells others. If you see a creature reduce another creature to 0 hit points, you can use your reaction to grant yourself a bonus to all damage rolls against the aggressor until the end of your next turn. The bonus equals your monk level.
Once you use this ability, you can't use it again until you finish a {@variantrule Short Rest|Ishiir} or a {@variantrule Long Rest|Ishiir}.
